column18: 10/08/2002: Three people were burned to death by rebels in Bouake, Cote d�Ivoire. The attackers placed tires around the victims necks and set the tires on fire. Wood and coal was also used to feed the flames.

column18: 03/04/2004: Twelve people were killed by unknown perpetrators during an attack on a cocoa-growing village, Gagnoa, in the center of Cote d�Ivoire. The victims were mostly of the Bete population. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.

column17: Incident occurred outside the town of Duekoue, around 400 kilometers northwest of the commercial capital Abidjan
column18: 06/01/2005: Forty-one Ivorian ethnic Guere civilians were killed and 64 others were injured outside Duekoue, Moyen-Cavally Region, Cote D'Ivoire, when an unidentified group of people attacked and burned several homes. Locals suspected government-backed militias.

column18: 01/02/2006: Unidentified gunmen attacked the two main military barracks in Akuedo, northeastern Abidjan, Ivory Coast, causing a battle with security forces that killed seven of the attackers and three security men. No group claimed responsibility, and dozens of the attackers were arrested.�

column18: 02/05/2007: A bomb exploded in a car at a military base in Tiebissou, Cote D'Ivoire; the two people in the car were injured. The perpetrators of this incident were unknown.  No claim of responsibility was reported.
column125: The soldier was in the military car with his civilian girlfriend when it exploded.

column18: 09/29/2000: Student activists attack the Le Liberal newspaper office in the Riviera II district in Abidjan, Cote d'Ivoire with rocks and stones. The group was called the Federation of University and High School Students of Cote d'Ivoire.
column58: Federation of Students and Scholars of Cote d'Ivoire (FESCI)
column97: Rocks and stones were used in the attack.

column17: The bus terminal in Adjame neighborhood
column18: 10/4/2000: A bomb exploded at the bus terminal in the Adjame neighborhood in Abidjan, Ivory Coast.  Four people were killed in the explosion and at least six were injured.  The explosion originated in an office used for storing luggage.  State television stated that the bombers, four Nigerian nationals, were the ones who were killed in the explosion.  The motive behind the attack is unknown.
column47: Civilians in the vicinity of the bus station
column108: A bomb exploded in a bus station
column125: State television states that the four dead individuals were actually the bombers; however, the source is less reputable and the validity of this claim should be questioned
